artifacts.name: Kandyan Sword (Kasthāne)
artifacts.materials: Forged steel blade; brass/silver hilt; wood; gemstone inlays
artifacts.function: Used in royal ceremonies, investitures, and as visible rank insignia. Carried by nobles during processions and occasionally used in ritualized demonstrations of martial skill; also part of diplomatic gift exchanges.
artifacts.symbolism: Embodies royal authority, protector role of the king, and the martial lineage of Kandyan aristocracy. The Makara/dragon motifs mark protective power and link to mythical guardians.
artifacts.notes: Hilt often shaped like a Makara (mythical sea-creature). Many examples show inlay work, ceremonial scabbards, and are inscribed or gifted as diplomacy tokens; some blades were intentionally blunted for ceremonial use.

artifacts.name: Japanese Katana
artifacts.materials: Folded tamahagane steel; ray-skin; silk cord
artifacts.function: Primary battlefield and dueling weapon historically; later a status and ritual item. Used in paired sets (daisho) and in ceremonial rites like seppuku/installation rituals; sometimes mounted at shrines.
artifacts.symbolism: Represents bushidō values (honor, loyalty, discipline). Considered an extension of the warrior’s identity — “soul of the samurai” — with ritualized care, mounting, and presentation.
artifacts.notes: Forged with folding and differential hardening (hamon). Tsuba (guard) often artistically decorated; many katanas have provenance records and smith signatures (mei).

artifacts.name: Geta Bera (Kandyan Drum)
artifacts.materials: Jackfruit wood body; cow/monkey hide heads; rope braces
artifacts.function: Provides the rhythmic backbone of Kandyan dance forms and ritual processions. Sets tempo for dancers, signals choreographic changes, and accompanies chant and percussion ensembles in temple ceremonies.
artifacts.symbolism: Signifies sacred beat linking community and deity; rhythmic patterns mark ritual phases and solemnity, and the drum’s sound is considered to call or please protective spirits.
artifacts.location: Kandy region temples; cultural dance schools
artifacts.notes: Double-headed construction tuned asymmetrically for tonal contrast. Drummers often undergo training that includes ritual purification; sticks and playing techniques are specific to each dance type (Ves, Naiyandi).

artifacts.name: Japanese Taiko Drum
artifacts.dimensions: Small hand drums up to 1–2 m
artifacts.materials: Hollowed zelkova or keyaki wood; animal hide
artifacts.function: Used for religious processions, ensemble performance (kumi-daiko), theatrical accompaniment (Noh/ Kabuki), and community signaling. In modern performance, taiko creates dramatic, choreographed ensemble shows.
artifacts.symbolism: Expresses communal cohesion, ritual presence, and the visceral power of sound; large taiko embody public energy and sacred force in festivals.
artifacts.notes: Variety of sizes; some taiko are portable for parades, others are massive and stationary. Contemporary groups (e.g., Kodo) have revived and globalized taiko performance.

artifacts.name: Kandyan Temple Mural
artifacts.materials: Lime plaster; mineral pigments; organic binders; occasional gold leaf
artifacts.function: Serves as didactic visual scripture: instructs lay patrons in Jataka tales and ethical precepts, supports liturgy, and visually anchors devotional space for worship. Murals also expressed royal patronage.
artifacts.symbolism: Symbolizes moral order, karmic consequences, and the sanctity of the monastic community; murals encode cosmology and ethical exemplars for believers.
artifacts.notes: Restricted palette (reds, yellows, blacks) and flattened perspective; pigments derived from local minerals and organic binders cause particular conservation needs. Many murals have layered retouching histories tied to temple restorations.

artifacts.name: Thai Temple Mural
artifacts.function: Narrates epic cycles and Buddhist instruction for devotees; murals are integrated with ritual procession routes and icon display. Commissioned by royal or monastic patrons for instruction and prestige.
artifacts.symbolism: Conveys royal religious legitimacy, cosmic order, and idealized moral conduct; gold leaf raises sacredness and signals elite sponsorship.
artifacts.notes: Highly detailed narrative registers, rich color palette and gold highlight; murals often reflect courtly aesthetics and include donor portraits.

artifacts.name: Sri Lankan Clay Pot
artifacts.materials: Local red/yellow clay; sand or organic temper
artifacts.function: Everyday vessel for cooking (esp. rice), water cooling and storage, fermenting foods, and sometimes ritual libations. Form and surface finish reflect function (pouring spouts, rims for lids).
artifacts.symbolism: Symbolic of domestic continuity, hospitality, and elemental connection to earth; pot forms are integrated into ritual food offerings and seasonal cycles.
artifacts.notes: Unglazed porous bodies allow evaporative cooling; traditional pots are made by coiling or wheel techniques and may be fired in open kilns. Decorative motifs vary regionally.

artifacts.name: Egyptian Amphora
artifacts.materials: Terracotta; slip coatings and painted pigments
artifacts.function: Long-distance transport containers for oil, wine, salted fish and grains; used in domestic storage and as grave goods. Shapes relate to shipping and storage efficiency.
artifacts.symbolism: Emblem of trade networks, wealth, and civic provisioning; decorated amphora often reflect mythological or civic identity.
artifacts.location: Archaeological sites in the Nile Delta; museums (e.g., British Museum)
artifacts.notes: Biconical bodies, twin handles and narrow necks optimized for stowage and pouring; painted or stamped indices can indicate contents or makers.

artifacts.name: Kolam Mask
artifacts.function: Central prop for Kolam performances — masks animate characters in satirical plays that comment on village life, social norms and morality. Also used in healing/demonstrative rites.
artifacts.symbolism: Embodies social critique and cultural memory; masks play dual roles as entertainment and social correction, often encoding local cosmologies.
artifacts.notes: Masks are carved to specific character types (villagers, demons, kings). Painted colors indicate temperament; lightweight woods chosen for mobility during dance.

artifacts.name: African Ritual Mask
artifacts.materials: Local hardwoods, natural pigments, beads, raffia
artifacts.function: Worn during initiation ceremonies, harvest rites, funerary and royal performances; often integrated with dance, music, and sacrifice. Masks activate social and spiritual functions.
artifacts.symbolism: Serve as intermediaries to ancestors and spirits; they mediate community identity, moral law, and fertility/protection rites.
artifacts.notes: Often part of a full costume ensemble; specific masks are restricted to initiated members and may be ritually charged (consecrated).

artifacts.name: Laksha Lacquerware
artifacts.materials: Seasoned wood, lac (natural resin), plant dyes
artifacts.function: Functional as containers for ritual substances, personal ornaments, or processional items; also used as decorative gifts and temple offerings.
artifacts.symbolism: Symbolizes refinement, prosperity, and continuity of handcraft lineage; lacquer sheen signals protection and value.
artifacts.notes: Made on lathes with successive lacquer layers rubbed to polish; patterns often use circular/spiral motifs; dyes come from local plant sources.

artifacts.name: Channapatna Lacquerware
artifacts.function: Domestic decorative objects and children’s toys; historically trade items.
artifacts.symbolism: Represents community-level artisan systems and regional identity; brightly colored forms connote cheerful domesticity.
artifacts.notes: Recognized with GI status; natural dyes and lacquering techniques are preserved through craft schools.

artifacts.name: Brass Oil Lamp (Pahana)
artifacts.function: Lit in temples, shrines and domestic altars during puja, processions and festivals; also used to inaugurate events and mark auspicious starts.
artifacts.symbolism: Represents dispelling of ignorance by light; lamp-lighting is both devotional act and social ritual signalling hospitality and blessing.
artifacts.notes: Often shaped with culturally resonant motifs (peacock, elephant). Permits multiple wicks; sometimes carried on processional poles.

artifacts.name: Indian Deepam Lamp
artifacts.function: Central in Hindu puja practice: lit before deities, used in arati and festival observances (e.g., Deepavali).
artifacts.symbolism: Symbolizes divine presence, prosperity and grace; light connects mundane to divine.
artifacts.notes: Lamps often form part of ritual paraphernalia set; some are richly ornamented with iconography of Lakshmi or Shiva.

artifacts.name: Beeralu Lace (Bobbin Lace)
artifacts.function: Used to embellish garments, religious textiles, and household linens; lace-making is a domestic craft that supported women’s incomes and social networks.
artifacts.symbolism: Represents fine handwork, female artistic labor, and cultural exchange (Portuguese influence).
artifacts.notes: Design complexity varies by locale; tools include lace pillows and pins. Some patterns are unique family motifs preserved across generations.

artifacts.name: Belgian Bobbin Lace
artifacts.function: High-status clothing, ecclesiastical vestments, ceremonial linens.
artifacts.symbolism: Signifies aristocratic taste, refinement and luxury craftsmanship.
artifacts.notes: Technique produces extremely fine openwork; lace patterns may identify region or workshop.

artifacts.name: Kurahan Gala / Miris Gala (Grinding Stone)
artifacts.function: Primary household implement for milling grains (kurakkan), spices and chilies; often used daily in food preparation and ritual food production.
artifacts.symbolism: Symbol of domestic continuity, female labor and food sovereignty; often inherits familial significance.
artifacts.notes: Hand-operated method imparts distinctive texture and flavor. Stone often kept as family heirloom with care.

artifacts.name: Mayan Metate
artifacts.function: Grinding maize and other staples for daily meals (tortillas), and in ritual contexts for offering preparations.
artifacts.symbolism: Represents female domestic role, sustenance, and cultural continuity; some metates have ritualized designs.
artifacts.notes: Often anthropomorphized in ceremonial pieces. Design and use persist in many communities.

artifacts.name: Sandakada Pahana (Moonstone)
artifacts.function: Placed at temple thresholds to mark and sanctify the transition from profane to sacred space; also tied to ritual movement during processions.
artifacts.symbolism: Embodies cosmological cycles (samsara), purity and progression toward liberation; animals and floral bands encode moral and cosmological meanings.
artifacts.notes: Carving follows a consistent banded program: outer flames, animals, creepers and central lotus. Moonstones are diagnostic of Sri Lankan Buddhist architecture.

artifacts.name: Indian Temple Threshold Stone
artifacts.function: Serves as entrance feature for temples, often used in ritual circumambulation and marking auspicious thresholds.
artifacts.symbolism: Represents purification, auspiciousness and protection; threshold carvings often include deities, lotus and guardian motifs.
artifacts.notes: Thresholds often integrated with carved doorframes (toranas) and elaborate lintels; iconography may vary by sectarian association (Shaiva/Vaishnava).

artifacts.name: Punkalasa (Pot of Plenty)
artifacts.function: Used as votive motif or temple ornament symbolizing abundance and invoked in harvest/royal rituals; sometimes present in temple iconography or processions.
artifacts.symbolism: Emblems of fertility, prosperity, and royal largesse — pot overflowing with produce denotes blessing and sustenance.
artifacts.notes: Often sculpted as part of temple friezes or freestanding vessels; may be painted or gilded in sacred contexts.

artifacts.name: Greek Cornucopia (Horn of Plenty)
artifacts.function: Used as votive and decorative motif in art and ritual scenes celebrating harvest and abundance.
artifacts.symbolism: Classical emblem of prosperity tied to agricultural gods (e.g., Demeter) and civic wellbeing.
artifacts.notes: Often depicted overflowing with fruit and grain; appears in funerary and domestic contexts.

artifacts.name: Wangediya Mortar (Granite mortar)
artifacts.function: Used to grind herbs, spices and prepare Ayurvedic pastes; essential in household and medicinal preparations.
artifacts.symbolism: Represents healing knowledge and domestic food technology passed through families.
artifacts.notes: Often heavy and durable; sometimes inscribed with maker marks; paired with wooden pestle (mol gaha).

artifacts.name: Japanese Suribachi Mortar
artifacts.function: Ideal for grinding sesame, spice blends and making sauces/condiments; kitchen staple for fine emulsification.
artifacts.symbolism: Embodies culinary refinement and ritualized food preparation in household kitchens.
artifacts.notes: Interior combed ridges (kushi) increase grinding efficiency; typically used with wooden pestle (surikogi).

artifacts.name: Kandyan Silver Jewelry (Nalalpati, Earrings)
artifacts.function: Worn for status display in weddings, temple offerings, dance costumes and as family heirlooms; used to identify caste/region in some contexts.
artifacts.symbolism: Signals wealth, ritual readiness, and regional identity; often linked to temple donation practices.
artifacts.location: Temple treasuries; private collections in Kandy
artifacts.notes: Features filigree, granulation, and repoussé techniques; jewelry documents trade ties via gem materials and stylistic influences.

artifacts.name: Mughal Silver Jewelry
artifacts.function: Designed for court display, ceremonial dress, and as diplomatic gifts; often part of imperial treasure.
artifacts.symbolism: Expresses imperial power, cosmopolitan taste (Persian influence) and devotional patronage.
artifacts.notes: Intricate stone settings, enamel work (meenakari) in some pieces; provenance can often be traced through court records.

artifacts.name: Wooden Pillar Carvings (Embekke-style)
artifacts.function: Structural posts for temple halls and palace pavilions that also carry narrative and decorative carving; integrate iconography with structural function.
artifacts.symbolism: Signify royal patronage, devotional stories, and skilled craft lineage; carved motifs may include protective and auspicious figures.
artifacts.location: Embekke Devalaya and other historic sites
artifacts.notes: Extremely high relief carving with dancers, wrestlers, floral patterns; joinery techniques avoid metal fasteners in some examples.

artifacts.name: Balinese Temple Wood Carvings
artifacts.function: Decorate temple gateways, shrines and domestic shrines; act as narrative surfaces and protective talismans.
artifacts.symbolism: Represent mythic stories (Ramayana/Mahabharata), guardian beings and auspicious symbols that protect the temple precinct.
artifacts.notes: Often painted/gilded; high relief with swirling vegetal patterns and animated guardian figures; carved by specialized families.

artifacts.name: Brass Betel Cutter (Bulath Kaduwa)
artifacts.function: Used during betel-chewing ceremonies to cut areca nut leaves and prepare betel offerings for guests and during rituals like weddings.
artifacts.symbolism: Signifies hospitality, reciprocal social bonds, and ritual courtesy; betel sets are important in social negotiation and ceremony.
artifacts.notes: Designs often stylized (birds, fish, religious motifs); part of a set that includes betel tray, lime box and nut pick.

artifacts.name: Chinese / SE Asian Areca Nut Cutter
artifacts.function: Used to slice areca nut for betel-chewing in social and ritual contexts; tool carried in social sets.
artifacts.symbolism: Emphasizes hospitality, social reciprocity, and ritualized daily practice across many Asian cultures.
artifacts.notes: Often engraved with dragons or auspicious emblems; used in both secular and ceremonial contexts.
